[[File:Map of USA UT.svg|thumb|Location of the [[state of Utah]] in the [[United States of America]]]] The U.S. state of [[Utah]] has 26 [[Lists of United States state insignia|official symbols]], as designated by the [[Utah State Legislature]], and three unofficial symbols. All official symbols, except the Great Seal, are listed in Title 63G of Utah Code.{{cite web | url=http://www.le.utah.gov/UtahCode/section.jsp?code=63G-1 | title=State Symbols and Designations| work=Utah Code | publisher=Utah State Legislature | accessdate=February 1, 2011}} In 1896, Utah became a state, and on April 3 the Utah legislature, in its first regular session, adopted its first symbol, the [[Seals of the U.S. states|Great Seal]] of the State of Utah. Many unique symbols of Utah are related to Utah's [[Mormon pioneers|pioneer]] heritage, such as the [[California gull]], the [[Beehive (beekeeping)|beehive]], the [[dutch oven]] and the [[Calochortus nuttallii|Sego Lily]]. Utah has symbols that are used by multiple states. For example, the [[Western honey bee|honey bee]], Utah's state insect, is also a symbol of [[Arkansas]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], [[Kansas]], [[Louisiana]], [[Maine]], [[Mississippi]], [[Missouri]], [[Nebraska]], [[New Jersey]], [[North Carolina]], [[West Virginia]] and [[Wisconsin]].{{cite web | url=http://www.gpnc.org/honeybee.htm | title=honeybee | publisher=Great Plains Nature Center | accessdate=February 1, 2011}} ==Official State symbols== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:center;" ! width=11% | Type ! width=21% | Symbol ! width=45% class=unsortable | Description ! width=8% | Adopted ! width=10% class=unsortable | Image ! width=5% class=unsortable | Source |- | '''[[List of U.S. state animals|Animal]]''' | [[Rocky Mountain elk]]
''Cervus canadensis nelsoni'' | Once found over most of the United State and Canada, elk herds have been decimated by hunting and habitat loss. Now, elk are only found in the [[Rocky Mountain]]s. State owned [[Hardware Ranch]] provides feed for 600 elk every winter.{{cite web | url=http://wildlife.utah.gov/publications/pdf/2010_elk.pdf | title=Rocky Mountain Elk | work=Wildlife Notebook Series No. 12 | publisher=Utah Division of Wildlife Resources | format=PDF | accessdate=February 2, 2011}} | 1971 | [[File:Cervus canadensis2006.jpg|100px]] | {{cite web | url=http://pioneer.utah.gov/research/utah_symbols/animal.html | title=Utah State Animal – Rocky Mountain Elk | work=Pioneer: Utah's Online Library | publisher=State of Utah | accessdate=December 9, 2010}} |- | '''[[Astronomy|Astronomical
symbol]]''' | [[Beehive Cluster]] | The Beehive Cluster is an [[open cluster]] of about 1,000 stars and is located in the constellation [[Cancer (constellation)|Cancer]]. It was named the state's astronomical symbol due to having the same name as the state's emblem and nickname. | 1996 | [[File:Messier 044 2MASS.jpg|100px]] | {{cite web | url=http://pioneer.utah.gov/research/utah_symbols/star.html | title=Utah State Star and Astronomical Symbol - Dubhe & the Beehive Cluster | work=Pioneer: Utah's Online Library | publisher=State of Utah | accessdate=December 12, 2010}} |- | '''[[List of U.S. state birds|Bird]]''' | [[California gull]]
''Larus californicus'' | Named the state bird in commemoration of the "[[miracle of the gulls]]". In 1848, the [[Mormon pioneers|pioneers]] where tending to their first harvest since they arrived in Utah, when [[Mormon cricket]] swarmed in and started to devour the crops. California gulls came in and ate the crickets, thus saving the crops. | 1955 | [[File:CaliforniaGull23.jpg|100px]] | {{cite web | url=http://pioneer.utah.gov/research/utah_symbols/bird.html | title=Utah State Bird – California Gull | work=Pioneer: Utah's Online Library | publisher=State of Utah | accessdate=December 9, 2010}} |- | '''[[Emblem]]''' | [[Beehive (beekeeping)|Beehive]] | The beehive symbolizes [[Beehive#Symbolism|industry]], which is the state's motto. Before the state of Utah, the provisional government of the [[State of Deseret]] also had the beehive as its emblem. [[Deseret (Book of Mormon)|Deseret]] means honeybee in the [[Book of Mormon]].{{citation |first= Richard D. |last= Poll |authorlink= Richard D. Poll |contribution-url= http://www.uen.org/utah_history_encyclopedia/d/DESERET.html |contribution= Deseret |editor-last= Powell |editor-first= Allan Kent |year= 1994 |title= Utah History Encyclopedia |location= Salt Lake City, Utah |publisher= [[University of Utah Press]] |isbn= 0874804256 |oclc= 30473917 }} The first bees brought to modern-day Utah were allegedly carried by Charles Crismon from the Mormon colony in [[San Bernardino]], [[California]]."[http://www.logoi.com/notes/mormon-arizona/californias-mormon-pilgrims.html California's Mormon Pilgrims]," accessed July 6, 2012. | 1959 | align="center"|[[File:Biskötsel, Vanlig halmkupa, Nordisk familjebok.png|100px]] | {{cite web | url=http://pioneer.utah.gov/research/utah_symbols/motto.html | title=Utah State Motto and Emblem | work=Pioneer: Utah's Online Library | publisher=State of Utah | accessdate=December 9, 2010}} |- | '''[[Cooking pot|Cooking Pot]]''' | [[Dutch oven|Dutch Oven]] | Dutch ovens were the primary cooking vessels of [[Mormon pioneers|pioneers]]. The World Championship Dutch Oven Cookoff is held every summer near [[Logan, Utah]]. | 1997 | align="center"|[[File:Dutch Oven -McClures Magazine.jpg|100px]] | {{cite web | url=http://pioneer.utah.gov/research/utah_symbols/cooking.html | title=Utah State Cooking Pot - Dutch Oven | work=Pioneer: Utah's Online Library | publisher=State of Utah | accessdate=December 12, 2010}} |- | '''[[List of U.S. state fish|Fish]]''' | [[Bonneville cutthroat trout|Bonneville Cutthroat Trout]]
''Oncorhynchus clarki Utah'' | In 1997, the state fish became the Bonneville Cutthroat Trout replacing the [[Rainbow Trout]], which had been the state fish since 1971. The Bonneville Cutthroat Trout is a native species to Utah, unlike the Rainbow Trout, and was an important source of food for the [[Mormon pioneers|pioneers]] and [[Native Americans in the United States|Native Americans]]. | 1997 | [[File:Bonneville cutthroat.jpg|100px]] |{{cite web | url=http://pioneer.utah.gov/research/utah_symbols/fish.html | title=Utah State Fish – Bonneville Cutthroat Trout | work=Pioneer: Utah's Online Library | publisher=State of Utah | accessdate=December 9, 2010}} |- | '''[[Flags of the U.S. states|Flag]]''' | The [[Flag of Utah]] | The state flag contains a beehive in the middle, the word "industry" above the beehive and [[Calochortus nuttallii|Sego Lilies]] growing on either side of the beehive. The [[bald eagle]], two [[Flag of the United States|American flags]], the date 1847, representing the year the [[Mormon pioneers|pioneers]] arrived in Utah, and the date 1896, the year Utah became a state. | 1913 | [[File:Flag of Utah.svg|100px|Utah State Flag]] | {{cite web | url=http://pioneer.utah.gov/research/utah_symbols/flag.html | title=Utah State Flag and Seal | work=Pioneer: Utah's Online Library | publisher=State of Utah | accessdate=December 9, 2010}} |- | '''[[List of U.S. state flowers|Flower]]''' | [[Calochortus nuttallii|Sego Lily]]
''Calochortus nuttallii'' | The bulbs of the Sego Lily were used as food for the [[Native Americans in the United States|Native Americans]] and for the [[Mormon pioneers]] when food became scarce. | 1911 | [[File:Sego lily cm.jpg|100px]] | {{cite web | url=http://pioneer.utah.gov/research/utah_symbols/flower.html | title=Utah State Flower – Sego Lily | work=Pioneer: Utah's Online Library | publisher=State of Utah | accessdate=December 9, 2010}} |- | '''[[List of U.S. state dances|Dance]]''' | [[Square dance]] | Andrew Love Neff, in his book History of ''Utah 1847-1869'', says "The Mormons love dancing... almost every third man is a fiddler, and every one must learn to dance... Let it be remembered that only square dances were indulged in."{{cite book | last1=Neff | first1=Andrew Love | last2=Creer | first2=Leland Hargrave | title=Utah 1847-1869 | publisher=Deseret News Press | location=Salt Lake City | year=1940 }} | 1994 | [[File:Western Square Dance Group.jpg|100px|alt=A group of dancers in colorful Western clothing promenading in a circle, with a man speaking into a microphone on a stage in the background.|The [[square dance]], Oregon's state dance.]] | {{cite web | url=http://pioneer.utah.gov/research/utah_symbols/dance.html | title=Utah State Folk Dance - Square Dance | work=Pioneer: Utah's Online Library | publisher=State of Utah | accessdate=February 1, 2011}} |- | '''[[List of U.S. state firearms|Firearm]]''' | ''[[M1911 pistol|Browning M1911]]'' | Named due to inventor [[John Browning]]'s ties to Utah. |2011 | [[File:M1911 pistol.jpg|100px]] |{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-12792633 | title=Utah designates Browning M1911 official state firearm | publisher=[[BBC News]] | accessdate=March 19, 2011 | date=March 18, 2011}} |- | '''[[List of U.S. state fossils|Fossil]]''' | ''[[Allosaurus]]'' | A meat eater and the most common [[Theropod]] that lived during the late [[Jurassic]] period. Utah's [[Cleveland-Lloyd Dinosaur Quarry]] contains the densest concentration of Jurassic period fossils ever found and has more ''Allosaurus'' fossils have been found at the Quarry than any where else.{{cite book | last=Madsen | first=James H., Jr. | origyear=1976 | year=1993 | title=''Allosaurus fragilis'': A Revised Osteology | series=Utah Geological Survey Bulletin '''109''' | publisher=Utah Geological Survey | location=Salt Lake City | edition=2nd | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Mn9VMNmT2RsC | accessdate=February 2, 2011| isbn=9781557910769 }} The [[University of Utah]]'s [[Utah Museum of Natural History]] has the world's largest collection of ''Allosaurus'' fossils.{{cite web | url=http://umnh.utah.edu/dinosaursofutah | title=Dinosaurs of Utah | publisher=Utah Museum of Natural History | accessdate=February 2, 2011 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100927213000/http://umnh.utah.edu/dinosaursofutah | archivedate=September 27, 2010 | df= }} | 1988 | [[File:Allosaurus BW.jpg|100px]] | {{cite web | url=http://pioneer.utah.gov/research/utah_symbols/fossil.html | title=Utah State Fossil - Allosaurus | work=Pioneer: Utah's Online Library | publisher=State of Utah | accessdate=December 12, 2010}} |- | '''[[List of U.S. state fruits|Fruit]]''' | [[Cherry]]
''Prunus avium'' | Cherries are a major fruit crop in the state of Utah. Cherry trees, given by [[Japan]] just after World War II, line the [[Utah State Capitol]] grounds. | 1997 | [[File:Rainier Cherries.JPG|100px]] | {{cite web | url=http://pioneer.utah.gov/research/utah_symbols/fruit.html | title=Utah State Fruit – The Cherry | work=Pioneer: Utah's Online Library | publisher=State of Utah | accessdate=December 9, 2010}} |- |'''[[List of U.S. state minerals, rocks, stones and gemstones|Gem]]''' |[[Topaz]] |The semiprecious crystal is made from [[silicon]], [[aluminium]] and [[fluorine]]. Utah topaz can be yellow, gold, red and pink in color. It is found in [[Juab County, Utah|Juab]], [[Tooele County, Utah|Tooele]] and [[Beaver County, Utah|Beaver]] counties. |1969 |[[File:Topaz-27da.jpg|100px]] |{{cite web | url=http://pioneer.utah.gov/research/utah_symbols/gem.html | title=Utah State Gem - Topaz | work=Pioneer: Utah's Online Library | publisher=State of Utah | accessdate=December 12, 2010}} |- | '''[[List of U.S. state grasses|Grass]]''' | [[Indian ricegrass|Indian Ricegrass]]
''Achnatherum hymenoides'' | Indian ricegrass is a [[Perennial plant|perennial]] [[bunchgrass]]. The ricegrass is a vital food source for animals as it starts to produces green shoots in late winter and into spring, before other food sources start to grow. [[Native Americans in the United States|Native Americans]] would turn the seeds into flour for bread.{{cite web | url=http://www.fs.fed.us/database/feis/plants/graminoid/achhym/all.html | title=SPECIES: Achnatherum hymenoides | work=FEIS Reviews: Plant Species | publisher=U.S. Forest Service | accessdate=February 2, 2011}} | 1990 | [[File:Achnatherum hymenoides - Ricegrass.jpg|100px]] | {{cite web | url=http://pioneer.utah.gov/research/utah_symbols/grass.html | title=Utah State Grass – Indian Ricegrass | work=Pioneer: Utah's Online Library | publisher=State of Utah | accessdate=December 9, 2010}} |- | '''[[List of U.S. state songs|Hymn]]''' | ''[[Utah, We Love Thee]]'' | Utah's original state song from 1936 to 2003. The song was written in 1895 by [[Evan Stephens]] for celebrations held in 1896, when Utah became a state. | 2003 | align="center"|[[File:Utah We Love Thee.png|100px]] | {{cite web | url=http://pioneer.utah.gov/research/utah_symbols/song.html | title=Utah State Song - "Utah, This is the Place" | work=Pioneer: Utah's Online Library | publisher=State of Utah | accessdate=December 12, 2010}} |- | '''[[List of U.S. state insects|Insect]]''' | [[Western honey bee|Honey Bee]]
''Apis mellifera'' | Utah's nickname is the beehive state. Utah was first called the [[State of Deseret]] with [[Deseret (Book of Mormon)|Deseret]] meaning honeybee in the [[Book of Mormon]]. | 1983 | [[File:Apis mellifera bi.jpg|100px]] | {{cite web | url=http://pioneer.utah.gov/research/utah_symbols/insect.html | title=Utah State Insect – Honey Bee | work=Pioneer: Utah's Online Library | publisher=State of Utah | accessdate=December 9, 2010}} |- | '''[[List of official languages by state|Language]]''' | [[English language|English]] | Utah voters approved Initiative A on the 2000 ballot to make English become the official language. | 2000 |— | {{cite web | url=http://le.utah.gov/~code/TITLE63G/htm/63G01_020100.htm | title=Official State Language | work=Utah Code | publisher=Utah State Legislature | accessdate=February 1, 2011 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101106020259/http://le.utah.gov/~code/TITLE63G/htm/63G01_020100.htm | archivedate=November 6, 2010 | df= }}{{cite web | url=http://www.rules.utah.gov/execdocs/2000/p2000-11-28.htm | title=Stating the Outcome of Voting on Initiative Petitions on the Ballot for the 2000 General Election | work=Executive Documents | publisher=State of Utah | accessdate=February 8, 2011}} |- | '''[[List of U.S. state minerals, rocks, stones and gemstones|Mineral]]''' | [[Copper]] | Utah is home to the [[Bingham Canyon Mine|Bingham Canyon Open Pit Copper Mine]], which has produced copper since 1906. The mine has produced more copper than any other mine in history.{{cite web | url=http://www.kennecott.com/visitors-center/amazing-facts/ | title=Kennecott Copper: Amazing Facts | publisher=Kennecott Copper | accessdate=February 2, 2011}} | 1994 | [[File:Copper.jpg|100px]] | {{cite web | url=http://pioneer.utah.gov/research/utah_symbols/mineral.html | title=Utah State Mineral - Copper | work=Pioneer: Utah's Online Library | publisher=State of Utah | accessdate=December 12, 2010}} |- | '''[[List of U.S. state mottos|Motto]]''' | Industry | The beehive symbolizes [[Beehive#Symbolism|industry]]. Industry appears on the state flag and the Great Seal of the State of Utah. | 1959 | — | |- | '''[[List of U.S. state minerals, rocks, stones and gemstones|Rock]]''' | [[Coal]] | Coal mines in [[Carbon County, Utah|Carbon]] and [[Emery County, Utah|Emery]] counties have been operating since 1881.{{cite web | url=http://historytogo.utah.gov/utah_chapters/mining_and_railroads/oldkingcoal.html | title=Old King Coal—A Long, Colorful Story | work=Utah History to Go | publisher=State of Utah | accessdate=February 3, 2011}} | 1991 | [[File:Coal anthracite.jpg|100px]] | {{cite web | url=http://pioneer.utah.gov/research/utah_symbols/rock.html | title=Utah State Rock - Coal | work=Pioneer: Utah's Online Library | publisher=State of Utah | accessdate=December 12, 2010}} |- | '''[[Seals of the U.S. states|Seal]]''' | [[Seal of Utah|The Great Seal of the State of Utah]] | The state seal contains a beehive in the middle, the word "industry" above the beehive and [[Calochortus nuttallii|Sego Lilies]] growing on either side of the beehive. The [[bald eagle]], two [[Flag of the United States|American flags]], the date 1847, representing the year the [[Mormon pioneers|pioneers]] arrived in Utah, and the date 1896, the year Utah became a state. | 1896 | [[File:Seal of Utah (2011).svg|100px|Seal of Utah]] | {{cite web | url=http://le.utah.gov/~code/TITLE67/htm/67_01a000800.htm | title=Form and contents of great seal | work=Utah Code | publisher=Utah State Legislature | accessdate=February 1, 2011 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110815170009/http://le.utah.gov/~code/TITLE67/htm/67_01a000800.htm | archivedate=August 15, 2011 | df= }} |- | '''[[List of U.S. state songs|Song]]''' | ''[[Utah, This is the Place]]'' | Written in 1996 for Utah's centennial celebration, it became the state song because school children "didn't like the current state song, Utah We Love Thee... that it wasn't very much fun to sing." Legislation presented by Dana Chambers Love on behalf of 4th graders from Davis county changed the song in 2003. | 2003 | — | {{cite web | url=http://pioneer.utah.gov/research/utah_symbols/hymn.html | title=Utah State Hymn - "Utah, We Love Thee" | work=Pioneer: Utah's Online Library | publisher=State of Utah | accessdate=December 12, 2010}} |- | '''[[Star]]''' | [[Alpha Ursae Majoris|Dubhe]]
''Alpha Ursae Majoris'' | One of the stars composing the [[Big Dipper]]. Dubhe was chosen in 1996, the state's centennial, as it was supposedly 100 light years away. In actuality, the star is 124 light years away.{{cite web | url=http://stars.astro.illinois.edu/sow/dubhe.html | title=Dunhe | work=STARS | publisher=University of Illinois | accessdate=February 8, 2011}} | 1996 | — | |- | '''[[List of U.S. state tartans|Tartan]]''' | Utah State Centennial [[Tartan]] | The Utah State Centennial Tartan represents the tartans worn by the [[Clan Logan|Logan]] and [[Clan Skene|Skene]] [[Scottish clan]]s. [[Fur traders]] Ephraim Logan and [[Peter Skene Ogden]] explored Utah in the 1820s. The cities of [[Logan, Utah|Logan]] and [[Ogden, Utah|Ogden]] as well as the [[Logan River (Utah)|Logan River]] and the [[Ogden River]] are named after them. | 1996 | — | {{cite web | url=http://pioneer.utah.gov/research/utah_symbols/tartan.html | title=Utah State Centennial Tartan | work=Pioneer: Utah's Online Library | publisher=State of Utah | accessdate=December 12, 2010}} |- | '''[[List of U.S. state trees|Tree]]''' | [[Populus tremuloides|Quaking Aspen]]
''Populus tremuloides'' | The 80,000-year-old [[Pando (tree)|Pando]] aspen grove in central Utah is also considered to be among the Earth's largest and oldest living organisms.{{cite web | url=http://www.nps.gov/brca/naturescience/quakingaspen.htm | title=Quaking Aspen | publisher=[[Bryce Canyon]] [[National Park Service]] | accessdate=March 27, 2014}} The state tree was the Colorado [[blue spruce]], prior to 2014.{{cite web |url=http://pioneer.utah.gov/research/utah_symbols/tree.html |title=Utah State Tree - Aspen |author= |date=2014 |website=http://pioneer.utah.gov/ |publisher=Pioneer, Utah's Online Library |accessdate=Jan 25, 2015}} | 2014 | [[File:Quaking aspen Populus tremuloides trio.jpg|100px]] | {{cite web | url=http://www.ksl.com/?sid=29222272&nid=148&title=utah-state-tree-changes-thanks-to-elementary-students&s_cid=queue-7 | title=Utah state tree changes thanks to elementary students | work=KSL.com | publisher=KSL | accessdate=March 27, 2014}} |- | '''[[List of U.S. state foods|Vegetable]]''' | [[Spanish sweet onion]]
''Allium cepa'' | The onion is a major crop in [[Box Elder County, Utah|Box Elder]] and [[Weber County, Utah|Weber]] counties. | 2002 |— | {{cite web | url=http://pioneer.utah.gov/research/utah_symbols/vegetable.html | title=Utah State Tree – Spanish Sweet Onion and Sugar Beet | work=Pioneer: Utah's Online Library | publisher=State of Utah | accessdate=December 9, 2010}} |- | '''[[List of U.S. state foods|Vegetable]],'''
'''Historic''' | [[Sugar Beet]]
''Beta vulgaris'' | Sugar production in Utah was a huge enterprise from 1891 till 1920 and was dominated by the [[Utah-Idaho Sugar Company]]. A [[blight]], caused by the [[beet curly top virus]], severely dampened production until 1934. Production continued to drop from pressures of cheaper foreign sugar until there were no sugar factories left in Utah by 1980.{{citation |url= http://www.uen.org/utah_history_encyclopedia/s/SUGAR_INDUSTRY.html |title= The Sugar Industry in Utah |last= Arrington |first= Leonard J. |authorlink= Leonard J. Arrington |editor-last= Powell |editor-first= Allan Kent |year= 1994 |work= Utah History Encyclopedia |location= Salt Lake City, Utah |publisher= [[University of Utah Press]] |isbn= 0874804256 |oclc= 30473917 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20131101161046/http://www.uen.org/utah_history_encyclopedia/s/SUGAR_INDUSTRY.html |archivedate= 2013-11-01 |df= }} | 2002 | [[File:SugarBeet.jpg|100px]] | |} ==Unofficial State symbols== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:center;" ! width=11% | Type ! width=21% | Symbol ! width=45% class=unsortable | Description ! width=8% | Adopted ! width=10% class=unsortable | Image ! width=5% class=unsortable | Source |- | '''[[List of U.S. state nicknames|Nickname]]''' | The Beehive State | The Beehive is a common symbol of Utah, with the state motto, seal, flag and emblem related to bees or the beehive. | Traditional | — |{{cite web | url=http://travel.utah.gov/traveltrade/documents/US_GoWest_UT.pdf | title=Unique Utah | publisher=Utah Office of Tourism | format=PDF | accessdate=December 9, 2010 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717081048/http://travel.utah.gov/traveltrade/documents/US_GoWest_UT.pdf | archivedate=July 17, 2011 | df= }} |- | '''Slogan''' | "Utah: Life Elevated" | Designed to market Utah for tourism and business, the slogan alludes to Utah's mountains, its snow and [[skiing]]. Past slogans have included, "greatest snow on earth" and "Utah: This is Still the Right Place". | 2006 |— | {{cite news | url=http://www.ksl.com/?nid=148&sid=174290 | title="Life Elevated" Is Utah's New Slogan | publisher=KSL | date=March 10, 2006 | accessdate=February 3, 2011}} |- |- | '''[[List of U.S. state foods|Snack]]''' | [[Green Jell-O]] | Not an official state symbol as Jell-O, [[Mormon Corridor#"Jell-O Belt"|as a symbol]], does not appear in Utah Law. A [[simple resolution]] by the Senate of the state of Utah was passed recognizing Jell-O as a favorite snack food of Utah. | 2001 | [[File:Day 18 - Still Eating The Green Jello (gifrancis).jpg|100px]] | {{cite web | url=http://www.le.state.ut.us/~2001/bills/sbillenr/SR0005.htm | title=Resolution Urging Jell-O® Recognition | publisher=Utah State Legislature | year=2001 | accessdate=Oct 27, 2014}} |} ==See also== * [[Symbolism in The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] ==References== ;General {{refbegin}} *{{cite web | url=http://pioneer.utah.gov/research/utah_symbols/index.html | title=Symbols of Utah | work=Pioneer: Utah's Online Library | publisher=State of Utah | accessdate=September 8, 2008}} *{{cite web | url=http://le.utah.gov/~code/TITLE63G/htm/63G01_060100.htm | title=Utah Code – Section 601 State symbols | publisher=Utah State Legislature | accessdate=September 8, 2008 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080916005355/http://le.utah.gov/~code/TITLE63G/htm/63G01_060100.htm | archivedate=September 16, 2008 | df= }} {{refend}} ;Specific {{Reflist|2}} {{-}} {{Utah}} {{state symbols|}} [[Category:Lists of United States state symbols by state|Utah]] [[Category:Symbols of Utah| ]] [[Category:Utah-related lists|State symbols]]

page.title: List of aspect ratios of national flags

revision.text:
The following table shows the [[aspect ratio]] (height to width ratio) of [[national flag]]s used by countries and dependencies. Variant flags such as [[ensign]]s are listed in the "Alternative flags" column, if they have different proportions from the national flag. Territories without an official flag distinct from that of their controlling country are excluded. The ratios used most commonly are 2:3, used by 89 of 195 sovereign states, and 1:2, used by 54 sovereign states. Most dependencies and former colonies use the same proportions as their mother countries: all [[British Overseas Territories]] use 1:2 ratios, while the flags of most former and current Dutch and French areas have 2:3 proportions. For comparison, the ratios are also given as a decimal number, which is the flag width divided by its height (e.g. a 2:3 flag has a decimal ratio of {{sfrac|3|2}} = 1.5). Flags with [[Irrational number|irrational]] ratios have only a decimal approximation, and have the exact form given in the "Notes" column. Legend: * '''Bold''': [[List of sovereign states|Sovereign states]] (UN members and observers) * '''''Bold italics''''': [[List of states with limited recognition|States with limited recognition]] * ''Italics'': [[Dependent territory|Dependencies]], [[Constituent state|constituent countries]], and other non-sovereign territories Click on the "Flag" header to sort by status: first sovereign states, then ''de facto'' countries, then dependencies. ==Main list== {| class="wikitable sortable" ! Flag ! Country/Dependency ! Ratio ! class="unsortable" | Alternative flags ! class="unsortable" | Sources and notes |- id="Abkhazia" | {{hs|B}} [[File:Flag of Abkhazia.svg|x40px|border|alt=]] | '''''[[Flag of Abkhazia|Abkhazia]]''''' | {{nts|2|prefix=1:2 (}}) | | "The ratio of the length to the width of the flag is 2:1." — [https://web.archive.org/web/20070928080832/http://www.abkhaziagov.org/ru/state/sovereignty/symbols.php State Symbols — President of the Republic of Abkhazia] Claimed by [[#Georgia|Georgia]] as the [[Autonomous Republic of Abkhazia]], whose government in exile has a more squarish [[Flag of Abkhazia#Autonomous Republic of Abkhazia|unofficial flag]]. |- id="Afghanistan" | {{hs|A}} [[File:Flag of Afghanistan.svg|x40px|border|alt=]] | '''[[Flag of Afghanistan|Afghanistan]]''' | {{nts|1.5|prefix=2:3 (}}) | | "The flag of Afghanistan shall be made up of three equal parts. (...) The width of every color [stripe] shall be half of its length." ([http://moj.gov.af/en/page/1684 The Constitution of Afghanistan] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140407071355/http://moj.gov.af/en/page/1684 |date=2014-04-07 }}). The total width is therefore {{math|3 ⋅ {{sfrac|1|2}} {{=}} {{sfrac|3|2}}}} times the flag height. From 2001 until 2004, a 1:2 version of the flag was used. |- id="Albania" | {{hs|A}} [[File:Flag of Albania.svg|x40px|border|alt=]] | '''[[Flag of Albania|Albania]]''' | {{nts|1.4|prefix=5:7 (}}) | Civil, state and naval ensigns: 2:3 | "{{lang|sq|Përmasat e flamurit kombëtar përcaktohen ne raportin 1 me 1,4 njësi.}}" (The dimensions of the national flag are set in the ratio of 1 to 1.4 units.) — [[commons:File:Ligji 8926 22.07.2002.pdf|Law 8926, 22 July 2002 (at Commons)]] |- id="Algeria" | {{hs|A}} [[File:Flag of Algeria.svg|x40px|border|alt=]] | '''[[Flag of Algeria|Algeria]]''' | {{nts|1.5|prefix=2:3 (}}) | | |- id="American Samoa" | {{hs|C}} [[File:Flag of American Samoa.svg|x40px|border|alt=]] | ''[[Flag of American Samoa|American Samoa]]'' ([[#United States|US]]) | {{nts|2|prefix=1:2 (}}) | | |- id="Andorra" | {{hs|A}} [[File:Flag of Andorra.svg|x40px|border|alt=]] | '''[[Flag of Andorra|Andorra]]''' | {{nts|1.429|prefix=7:10 (}}) | | [http://www.identitat-institucional.ad/images/stories/docs/2_Bandera.pdf Official construction sheet — Govern d'Andorra Identitat Institucional]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}; the flag width is shown as twice 0.50* L, while the height is 0.70*L. |- id="Angola" | {{hs|A}} [[File:Flag of Angola.svg|x40px|border|alt=]] | '''[[Flag of Angola|Angola]]''' | {{nts|1.5|prefix=2:3 (}}) | | |- id="Anguilla" | {{hs|C}} [[File:Flag of Anguilla.svg|x40px|border|alt=]] | ''[[Flag of Anguilla|Anguilla]]'' ([[#United Kingdom|UK]]) | {{nts|2|prefix=1:2 (}}) | | The 1967–1969 [[Republic of Anguilla]]'s "[[Dolphin Flag]]" has a ratio of 3:5. |- id="Antigua and Barbuda" | {{hs|A}} [[File:Flag of Antigua and Barbuda.svg|x40px|border|alt=]] | '''[[Flag of Antigua and Barbuda|Antigua and Barbuda]]''' | {{nts|1.5|prefix=2:3 (}}) | | |- id="Argentina" | {{hs|A}} [[File:Flag of Argentina.svg|x40px|border|alt=]] | '''[[Flag of Argentina|Argentina]]''' | {{nts|1.6|prefix=5:8 (}}) | Civil flag and ensign (without the sun): 9:14 | |- id="Armenia" | {{hs|A}} [[File:Flag of Armenia.svg|x40px|border|alt=]] | '''[[Flag of Armenia|Armenia]]''' | {{nts|2|prefix=1:2 (}}) | | "The width-length ratio of the flag is 1/2" — [http://www.gov.am/en/official/ The Government of the Republic of Armenia] |- id="Artsakh" | {{hs|B}} [[File:Flag of Artsakh.svg|x40px|border|alt=]] | '''''[[Flag of the Republic of Artsakh|Artsakh]]''''' | {{nts|2|prefix=1:2 (}}) | | |- id="Aruba" | {{hs|C}} [[File:Flag of Aruba.svg|x40px|border|alt=]] | ''[[Flag of Aruba|Aruba]]'' ([[#Netherlands|Netherlands]]) | {{nts|1.5|prefix=2:3 (}}) | | "{{lang|nl|[D]e verhoudingen van de breedte tot de lengte van de vlag zijn 2 : 3.}}" (The proportion of the height to the length of the flag is 2:3.) — [http://www.overheid.aw/index.asp?nmoduleid=4&wgid=6&spagetype=6&docid=291 Landsverordening vlag, wapen en volkslied (Regulation of national flag, coat of arms and anthem) — Government of Aruba] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140407063848/http://www.overheid.aw/index.asp?nmoduleid=4&wgid=6&spagetype=6&docid=291 |date=2014-04-07 }} (PDF file) |- id="Australia" | {{hs|A}} [[File:Flag of Australia.svg|x40px|border|alt=]] | '''[[Flag of Australia|Australia]]''' | {{nts|2|prefix=1:2 (}}) | |"[The flag] is twice as long as it is wide" — [http://www.anbg.gov.au/oz/flag.html Department of the Environment and Water Resources — Australian Government] |- id="Austria" | {{hs|A}} [[File:Flag of Austria.svg|x40px|border|alt=]] | '''[[Flag of Austria|Austria]]''' | {{nts|1.5|prefix=2:3 (}}) | | |- id="Azerbaijan" | {{hs|A}} [[File:Flag of Azerbaijan.svg|x40px|border|alt=]] | '''[[Flag of Azerbaijan|Azerbaijan]]''' | {{nts|2|prefix=1:2 (}}) | | "Width of the flag constitutes half of its length" — [http://www.president.gov.az/azerbaijan/constitution/?locale=en Constitution of Azerbaijan — Website of the President of Azerbaijan] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130730172835/http://www.president.gov.az/azerbaijan/constitution/?locale=en |date=2013-07-30 }} |- id="Bahamas" | {{hs|A}} [[File:Flag of the Bahamas.svg|x40px|border|alt=]] | '''[[Flag of the Bahamas|Bahamas]]''' | {{nts|2|prefix=1:2 (}}) | | |- id="Bahrain" | {{hs|A}} [[File:Flag of Bahrain.svg|x40px|border|alt=]] | '''[[Flag of Bahrain|Bahrain]]''' | {{nts|1.667|prefix=3:5 (}}) | | |- id="Bangladesh" | {{hs|A}} [[File:Flag of Bangladesh.svg|x40px|border|alt=]] | '''[[Flag of Bangladesh|Bangladesh]]''' | {{nts|1.667|prefix=3:5 (}}) | Civil, naval and air force ensigns: 1:2 | "The ‘National Flag’ will be (...) in the proportion of length to width 10:6" — [http://www.pmo.gov.bd/pmolib/legalms/pdf/national-flag-rules.pdf People's Republic of Bangladesh Flag Rules, 1972] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090306172046/http://www.pmo.gov.bd/pmolib/legalms/pdf/national-flag-rules.pdf |date=2009-03-06 }} |- id="Barbados" | {{hs|A}} [[File:Flag of Barbados.svg|x40px|border|alt=]] | '''[[Flag of Barbados|Barbados]]''' | {{nts|1.5|prefix=2:3 (}}) | Naval ensign: 1:2 | "The dimensions of the National Flag shall be in the following proportions: (...) three to two (3:2)" — [http://www.gov.bb/bigportal/big/articles/showArticle.php?file=Flag_Etiquette.xml Flag Etiquette — Barbados Integrated Government] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150713225220/http://www.gov.bb/bigportal/big/articles/showArticle.php?file=Flag_Etiquette.xml |date=2015-07-13 }} |- id="Belarus" | {{hs|A}} [[File:Flag of Belarus.svg|x40px|border|alt=]] | '''[[Flag of Belarus|Belarus]]''' | {{nts|2|prefix=1:2 (}}) | | "The flag’s width-to-length ratio is 1 to 2" — [http://president.gov.by/en/symbols_en/ State symbols — President of the Republic of Belarus] |- id="Belgium" | {{hs|A}} [[File:Flag of Belgium.svg|x40px|border|alt=]] | '''[[Flag of Belgium|Belgium]]''' | {{nts|1.154|prefix=13:15 (}}) | Civil and naval ensigns: both 2:3 | The 2:3 version (also the civil ensign) is used more commonly on land than the 13:15 official flag. |- id="Belize" | {{hs|A}} [[File:Flag of Belize.svg|x40px|border|alt=]] | '''[[Flag of Belize|Belize]]''' | {{nts|1.5|prefix=2:3 (}}) | | |- id="Benin" | {{hs|A}} [[File:Flag of Benin.svg|x40px|border|alt=]] | '''[[Flag of Benin|Benin]]''' | {{nts|1.5|prefix=2:3 (}}) | | |- id="Bermuda" | {{hs|C}} [[File:Flag of Bermuda.svg|x40px|border|alt=]] | ''[[Flag of Bermuda|Bermuda]]'' ([[#United Kingdom|UK]]) | {{nts|2|prefix=1:2 (}}) | | |- id="Bhutan" | {{hs|A}} [[File:Flag of Bhutan.svg|x40px|border|alt=]] | '''[[Flag of Bhutan|Bhutan]]''' | {{nts|1.5|prefix=2:3 (}}) | | |- id="Bolivia" | {{hs|A}} [[File:Flag of For flags carried at sea the dimensions shall be two to one (2:1)." — [http://www.nalis.gov.tt/Research/SubjectGuide/NationalSymbols/NationalFlag/tabid/262/Default.aspx?PageContentMode=1 National Flag — Trinidad and Tobago National Library and Information System Authority] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150713215337/http://www.nalis.gov.tt/Research/SubjectGuide/NationalSymbols/NationalFlag/tabid/262/Default.aspx?PageContentMode=1 |date=2015-07-13 }} |- id="Tunisia" | {{hs|A}} [[File:Flag of Tunisia.svg|x40px|border|alt=]] | '''[[Flag of Tunisia|Tunisia]]''' | {{nts|1.5|prefix=2:3 (}}) | | |- id="Turkey" | {{hs|A}} [[File:Flag of Turkey.svg|x40px|border|alt=]] | '''[[Flag of Turkey|Turkey]]''' | {{nts|1.5|prefix=2:3 (}}) | | "Length of the Flag is one and half times of its width" — [http://denizmevzuat.udhb.gov.tr/dosyam/TÜRK%20BAYRAĞI%20TÜZÜĞÜ.doc Turkish Flag Regulations (Word document) — Republic of Turkey Ministry of Transport, Maritime Affairs and Communication Legislation Database]Genişlik (Width): G; Boy (Length): 1 1/2*G. — [http://mevzuat.meb.gov.tr/html/18171_0.html Turkish Flag — Ministry of National Education]The law stipulates that the flag should have a white hem (uçkurluk) at the hoist side, one thirtieth of the flag height wide, which would make the flag's aspect ratio 15:23. This hem however does not appear to be part of the flag design. |- id="Turkmenistan" | {{hs|A}} [[File:Flag of Turkmenistan.svg|x40px|border|alt=]] | '''[[Flag of Turkmenistan|Turkmenistan]]''' | {{nts|1.5|prefix=2:3 (}}) | | "{{lang|ru|Пропорции ширины полотнища к его длине составляют один к полтора.}}" (The proportion of the width of the flag to its length is one to one and a half.) — [http://turkmenistan.gov.tm/?id=3367 Государственный флаг Туркменистана как символ единства и независимости нации и нейтралитета государства — Turkmenistan Золотой Век] |- id="Turks and Caicos Islands" | {{hs|C}} [[File:Flag of the Turks and Caicos Islands.svg|x40px|border|alt=]] | ''[[Flag of the Turks and Caicos Islands|Turks and Caicos Islands]]'' ([[#United Kingdom|UK]]) | {{nts|2|prefix=1:2 (}}) | | |- id="Tuvalu" | {{hs|A}} [[File:Flag of Tuvalu.svg|x40px|border|alt=]] | '''[[Flag of Tuvalu|Tuvalu]]''' | {{nts|2|prefix=1:2 (}}) | | |- id="Uganda" | {{hs|A}} [[File:Flag of Uganda.svg|x40px|border|alt=]] | '''[[Flag of Uganda|Uganda]]''' | {{nts|1.5|prefix=2:3 (}}) | | |- id="Ukraine" | {{hs|A}} [[File:Flag of Ukraine.svg|x40px|border|alt=]] | '''[[Flag of Ukraine|Ukraine]]''' | {{nts|1.5|prefix=2:3 (}}) | Naval ensign 2:3 | |- id="United Arab Emirates" | {{hs|A}} [[File:Flag of the United Arab Emirates.svg|x40px|border|alt=]] | '''[[Flag of the United Arab Emirates|United Arab Emirates]]''' | {{nts|2|prefix=1:2 (}}) | | "{{lang|ar|.يكون علم دولة الإمارات العربية المتحدة مستطيل الشكل، طوله نصف عرضه،}}" (The flag of the United Arab Emirates is rectangular, the height half of the width.) "...of overall dimensions 3:2" — [http://www.parliament.gov.zm/sites/default/files/documents/acts/National%20Flag%20and%20Armorial%20Ensigns%20Act.pdf The National Flag and Armorial Ensigns Act — National Assembly of Zambia] |- id="Zimbabwe" | {{hs|A}} [[File:Flag of Zimbabwe.svg|x40px|border|alt=]] | '''[[Flag of Zimbabwe|Zimbabwe]]''' | {{nts|2|prefix=1:2 (}}) | | |- id="Åland" | {{hs|C}} [[File:Flag of Åland.svg|x40px|border|alt=]] | ''[[Flag of Åland|Åland]]'' ([[#Finland|Finland]]) | {{nts|1.529|prefix=17:26 (}}) | | |} ==Territories not included== * None of the thirteen [[Overseas France|overseas regions and territories of France]] except [[French Polynesia]], [[New Caledonia]] and the [[French Southern and Antarctic Lands]] have official flags other than the French tricolor. [[Flag of French Guiana|A flag]] for the department of [[French Guiana]] has been officially adopted, though this flag has not been approved by the regional council. Most of the other territories however have unofficial flags, and some of these flags are used locally. See [[Flags of the regions of France]]. * [[Akrotiri and Dhekelia]], Sovereign Base Areas of the United Kingdom, don't have an official [[Flag of Akrotiri and Dhekelia|flag]] other than the Union Jack. A reported green flag defaced with two golden lions is actually the flag of the Dhekelia Garrison, and is not an official flag of the entire territory.{{FOTW|id=cy%5Esba|anchor=dhe|title=Akrotiri and Dhekelia|accessdate=15 December 2014}} * The [[British Overseas Territory]] of [[Saint Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha]] has no separate flag and uses the Union Jack. The three constituent parts have their own flags, which all follow the "blue ensign with territorial arms" pattern of most other BOTs. See [[Flag of Saint Helena]], [[Flag of Ascension Island]] and [[Flag of Tristan da Cunha]]. * The nine [[United States Minor Outlying Islands]] don't have official flags, though there are unofficial local flags for five of the islands and island groups ([[Johnston Atoll]], the [[Midway Islands]], [[Palmyra Atoll]], [[Wake Island]] and [[Navassa Island]]). * None of the [[Dependencies of Norway|Norwegian overseas territories]] have flags. * [[Antarctica]] has no government and as such can't officially adopt a flag, though there are two proposed flags widely used to represent the continent: a blue flag by [[Graham Bartram]] and an orange flag by [[Whitney Smith]]. See [[Flags of Antarctica]]. ==Notes== {{Reflist|group=Note|refs= The exact width:height ratio of the flag of Nepal is:
\frac{24+\frac{297-180\sqrt{2}}{92-36\sqrt{2}}\cdot\left(1+\frac{8-3\sqrt{2}}{\sqrt{118-48\sqrt{2}}-6}\right)}{32+\frac{297-180\sqrt{2}}{92-36\sqrt{2}}\cdot\left(1+\frac{6}{\left(8-3\sqrt{2}\right)\cdot\left(\sqrt{1+\frac{18}{41-24\sqrt{2}}}-1\right)}\right)} = \frac{3 \left(40665857401448+2001055256793 \sqrt{2}+144 \sqrt{17 \left(10411242561157458401-2208656823577139226 \sqrt{2}\right)}\right)}{164926945077845} \approx 0.82033758776860084636 \ldots
 }} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Lists of flags}} [[Category:Lists and galleries of flags| Proportions]]

|[[Iceland]] || {{flag|Iceland}} ||align="right" | 350,710 ||align="right" | 101,826||align="right" | {{nts|3.4}} |2018 | |} == Least densely populated islands == There are numerous [[Desert island|uninhabited or deserted islands]]. The largest uninhabited island in the world is [[Devon Island]] in [[Canada]]. * [[Greenland]] (part of [[Denmark]]) population 56,452; area 2,166,086 square kilometres/836,109 square miles = 1 person per 38.37 square kilometres/14.81 square miles or 0.02 persons per square kilometre/0.06 persons per square mile. * [[Baffin Island]] (part of [[Nunavut]], [[Canada]]) population 11,000; area 507,451 square km/195,927.9 square mi = 1 person per 46.13 km2/17.81 sq mi or 0.02 persons per km2/0.05 persons per sq mi. * [[Victoria Island (Canada)]] population 1,875; area 217,291 km2/83,897 sq mi = 1 person per 115.88 km2/44.7 sq mi or 0.009 persons per km2/0.02 persons per sq mi. * [[Ellesmere Island]] (part of [[Nunavut]], [[Canada]]) population 146; area 196,235 km2/75,767 sq mi = 1 person per 1,344.08 km2/518.95 sq mi or 0.000744 persons per km2/0.0019 persons per sq mi. ==See also== {{Portal|Islands}} * [[List of islands]] * [[List of islands by population]] * [[List of islands by area]] * [[Populated islands of the Great Lakes]] * [[Hashima Island]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2010}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Islands by population density}} [[Category:Lists of islands| ]] [[Category:Geography-related lists]] [[Category:Lists by population density]]

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/Drpdsharma|Drpdsharma]] ([[User talk:Drpdsharma|talk]]) to last revision by Biogeographist. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{Psychology sidebar|lists}} This is an alphabetical '''list of psychotherapies'''.
See the main article [[psychotherapy]] for a description of what psychotherapy is and how it developed (see also [[counseling]], and the [[list of counseling topics]]).
This list contains some approaches that may not call themselves a psychotherapy but have a similar aim, of improving mental health and well being through talk and other means of communication.
In the 20th century, a great number of psychotherapies were created. All of these face continuous change in popularity, methods and effectiveness. Sometimes they are self-administered, either individually, in pairs, small groups or larger groups. However, a professional practitioner will usually use a combination of therapies and approaches, often in a team treatment process that involves reading/talking/reporting to other professional practitioners.
The older established therapies usually have a code of ethics, professional associations, training programs, and so on. The newer and innovative therapies may not yet have established these structures or may not wish to.
{{Compact ToC}}
== A == * [[Abreaction|Abreaction therapy]] * [[Accelerated experiential dynamic psychotherapy]] (AEDP) * [[Acceptance and commitment therapy]] (ACT) * [[Classical Adlerian psychotherapy|Adlerian therapy]] * [[Adventure therapy]] * [[Analytical psychology]] * [[Animal-assisted therapy]] * [[Art therapy]] * [[Attack therapy]] * [[Attachment-based psychotherapy]] * [[Attachment-based therapy (children)]] * [[Attachment therapy]] * [[Autogenic training]] * [[Aversion therapy]]
== B == * [[Behavioral activation]] * [[Behavior modification]] * [[Behaviour therapy|Behavior therapy]] * [[Bibliotherapy]] * [[Gerda Boyesen|Biodynamic psychotherapy]] * [[Bioenergetic analysis]] * [[Biofeedback]] * [[Body psychotherapy]] * [[Brief psychotherapy]]
== C == * [[Classical Adlerian psychotherapy]] * [[Chess therapy]] * [[Child psychotherapy]] * [[Person-centered therapy|Client-centered psychotherapy]] * [[Co-counselling]] * [[Cognitive analytic therapy]] * [[Cognitive therapy]] * [[Cognitive behavior therapy]] (CBT) * [[Coherence therapy]] * [[Collaborative therapy]] * [[Compassion focused therapy]] (CFT) * [[Concentrative movement therapy]] * [[Contemplative psychotherapy]] * [[Contextual therapy]] * [[Conversational model]] * [[Conversion therapy]]
== D == * [[Dance therapy]] or [[dance movement therapy]] (DMT) * [[Depth psychology]] * [[Daseinsanalysis]] * [[Developmental Needs Meeting Strategy]] (DNMS) * [[Dialectical behavior therapy]] (DBT) * [[Drama therapy]] * [[Dreamwork]] * [[Dyadic developmental psychotherapy]] (DDP)
== E == * [[Eclectic psychotherapy]] * [[Ecological counseling]] * [[Emotionally focused therapy]] (EFT) * [[Emotional Freedom Techniques]] (EFT) * [[T-groups|Encounter groups]] * [[Eye movement desensitization and reprocessing]] (EMDR) * [[Existential therapy]] * [[Exposure and response prevention]] * [[Expressive therapies]]
== F == * [[Family Constellations]] * [[Family therapy]] * [[Feminist therapy]] * [[Focusing (psychotherapy)]] * [[Psychoanalysis|Freudian psychotherapy]] * [[Functional analytic psychotherapy]] (FAP) * [[Future-oriented therapy]]
== G == * [[Gestalt therapy]] * [[Gestalt theoretical psychotherapy]] * [[Grief counseling]] * [[Group analysis]] * [[Group psychotherapy|Group therapy]] * [[Guided imagery|Guided affective imagery]]
== H == * [[Hakomi]] * [[Holotropic Breathwork]] * [[Attachment therapy|Holding therapy]] * [[Humanistic psychology]] * [[Human Givens]] * [[Hypnotherapy]]
== I == * [[Inner Relationship Focusing]] * [[Integrative body psychotherapy]] * [[Integral psychotherapy]] * [[Integrative psychotherapy]] * [[Intensive short-term dynamic psychotherapy]] * [[Internal Family Systems Model]] * [[Interpersonal psychoanalysis]] * [[Interpersonal psychotherapy]]
== J == * [[Journal therapy]] * [[Analytical psychology|Jungian psychotherapy]]
== L == * [[Logic-based therapy]] * [[Logotherapy]]
== M == * [[Relationship counseling|Marriage counseling]] * [[Integrative milieu model|Milieu therapy]] * [[Mindfulness-based cognitive therapy]] * [[Mindfulness-based stress reduction]] * [[Mentalization-based treatment]] * [[Metacognitive therapy]] * [[Method of levels]] (MOL) * [[Mode deactivation therapy]] (MDT) * [[Morita therapy]] * [[Motivational interviewing]] * [[Multimodal therapy]] * [[Multisystemic therapy]] * [[Multitheoretical psychotherapy]] * [[Music therapy]]
== N == * [[Narrative therapy]] * [[Nonviolent Communication]] * [[Nouthetic counseling]] * [[Nude psychotherapy]]
== O == * [[Object relations theory|Object relations psychotherapy]] * [[Orthodox psychotherapy]]
== P == * [[Parent–child interaction therapy]] * [[Parent management training]] * [[Pastoral counseling]] * [[Person-centered therapy]] * [[Play therapy]] * [[Poetry therapy]] * [[Positive psychology]] * [[Positive psychotherapy]] * [[Postural Integration]] * [[Primal therapy]] * [[Primal Integration]] * [[Process oriented psychology]] * [[Process psychology]] * [[Progressive counting (PC)]] * [[Prolonged exposure therapy]] * [[Provocative therapy]] * [[Psychedelic therapy]] * [[Psychoanalysis]] * [[Psychodrama]] * [[Psychodynamic psychotherapy]] * [[Psychosynthesis]] * [[Pulsing (bodywork)|Pulsing]]
== R == * [[Rational emotive behavior therapy]] (REBT) * [[Rational living therapy]] (RLT) * [[Reality therapy]] * [[Rebirthing-breathwork]] * [[Recovered-memory therapy]] * [[Reichian therapy]] * [[Relationship counseling]] * [[Relational-cultural therapy]] * [[Remote therapy]] * [[Person-centered therapy|Rogerian psychotherapy]]
== S == * [[Sandplay therapy]] * [[Schema therapy]] * [[Sensorimotor psychotherapy]] * [[Sexual identity therapy]] * [[Sex therapy]] * [[Social therapy]] * [[Solution focused brief therapy]] * [[Somatic experiencing]] * [[Somatic psychology]] * [[Status dynamic psychotherapy]] * [[Structural family therapy]] * [[Supportive psychotherapy]] * [[Systematic desensitization]] * [[Systemic therapy]]
== T == * [[T-groups]] * [[Therapeutic community]] * [[Thought Field Therapy]] * [[Transactional analysis]] * [[Transference focused psychotherapy]] * [[Transpersonal psychology]] * [[Transtheoretical model]] (TTM or "stages of change") * [[Twelve-step program]]s
== V == * [[Vegetotherapy]]
== W == * [[Wilderness therapy]] * [[Writing therapy]]
==See also== * [[List of cognitive–behavioral therapies]] * [[List of therapies]] {{Psychiatry}}
[[Category:Psychotherapy|*]] [[Category:Psychology lists|Psychotherapies]]

page.title: List of ubiquitous computing research centers

revision.comment: This is the first ubiquitous research center in Pakistan. Now has chapters in FAST-NU, Hamdard University and MAJU.
revision.text:
{{notability|lists|date=December 2015}} This is a list of notable institutions who claim to have a focus on [[Ubiquitous computing]] sorted by country:
== Pakistan == * Center for Research in Ubiquitous Computing (CRUC), Karachi, Pakistan.
== Canada == * [[Topological Media Lab]], Concordia University, Canada
== Finland == * Community Imaging Group, [[University of Oulu]], Finland
== Germany == * [[Telecooperation Office]] (TecO), [[Karlsruhe Institute of Technology]], Germany
== India == * Ubiquitous Computing Research Resource Centre (UCRC), [[Centre for Development of Advanced Computing]]<ref>http://deity.gov.in/content/ubiquitous-computing-projects-dpl-emerging-areas</ref>
== Sweden == * [[Mobile Life Centre]], Stockholm University
== United Kingdom == * Mixed Reality Lab, University of Nottingham
== References == {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:List Of Ubiquitous Computing Research Centers}} [[Category:Ubiquitous computing|Research Centers]] [[Category:Artificial intelligence laboratories]] [[Category:Human–computer interaction]] [[Category:Computing-related lists|Ubiquitous computing research centers]]

{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} '''MRK''' (Markos Kay) is a visual artist, creative director, illustrator and lecturer based in London, best known for his artificial life video art experiment "aDiatomea" (2007), a permanent exhibit at the [[Phyletic Museum]] in [[Jena]], Germany. His 3D generative short "The Flow" (2011) has been shown internationally as part of "Resonance" a collaboration of over 30 independent visual artists and sound designers. MRK's films have been exhibited worldwide, including OFFF Barcelona, [[Pause Fest]] Melbourne, [[Onedotzero]] London, Stroke Artfair Berlin and Viedram Rome.
== Biography ==
MRK graduated with a [[Master of Arts]] in [[Communication Design]] from [[Central St. Martins]] in 2007 and is currently working as a creative director, [[motion graphics|motion designer]] and lecturer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jotta.com/jotta/published/home/article/v2-published/1942/spotlight-markos-kay-and-the-generative-flow |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-05-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140826160925/http://www.jotta.com/jotta/published/home/article/v2-published/1942/spotlight-markos-kay-and-the-generative-flow |archivedate=26 August 2014 |df= }} "Jotta:Markos Kay"</ref>
In 2008, MRK released “aDiatomea,” an experimental piece that simulates [[diatoms]] consisting of realistic [[3d modeling|3d generated]] diatoms.<ref>[http://algorithmic-worlds.net/blfiog/blog.php?Post=20100123]{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} "Algorithmic Worlds"</ref> Each variant of these mathematical creatures is classified in actual [[Taxonomy (biology)|taxonomies]], giving Victorian diatom art a 21st-century redux.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://okological.tumblr.com/post/5574305704/adiatomea-by-mrk-adiatomea-are-a-series-of |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-05-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304031126/http://okological.tumblr.com/post/5574305704/adiatomea-by-mrk-adiatomea-are-a-series-of |archivedate=4 March 2016 |df= }} "Okological: aDiatomea"</ref> [[Granular synthesis|Granular sound]] is 'injected' into the diatoms affecting their form and movement, creating a [[dynamic system]].<ref>[http://dataisnature.com/?p=564] "Dataisnature"</ref> In 2012, "aDiatomea" was part of the official selection at Imagine Science Films in New York.<ref>[http://www.imaginesciencefilms.org/2012/10/10/the-flow/] "Imagine Science Films"</ref>
In 2011, he took part in "Resonance," an international collaboration of over 30 independent visual artists and sound designers, with the short film "The Flow." Resonance premiered at the [[OFFF]] 2011 festival, and went on to become an international success.<ref>[http://motionographer.com/2011/06/17/resonance-2/] "Motionographer: Resonance"</ref> The Flow deals with the idea of [[emergence]] and [[supervenience]] in the [[quantum]] and [[matter|physical worlds]].<ref>[http://www.mrkism.com/flow/] "The Flow"</ref> In 2012, a segment of "The Flow" was featured in [[Breaking Bad]] season 5, episode 3. This coincided with the release of an annotated and extended version of the film.<ref>[http://vimeo.com/45835137]"The Flow (annotated)</ref> "The Flow" composers Echoic Audio won Best Sound Design at the Van d'Or Awards 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cannesinavan.com/mobile-film-festival/the-van-dor-award-winners-2012/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-09-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121010100115/http://www.cannesinavan.com/mobile-film-festival/the-van-dor-award-winners-2012/ |archivedate=10 October 2012 |df= }}"The Van D'Or Award Winners 2012"</ref>
During 2012, in collaboration with [[seeper]], he directed large scale [[projection mapping]] events including the launch of [[Titanic Belfast]], Birmingham's [[Wings of Desire]] and the [[Vimeo]] Awards 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.idfb.co.uk/news/2012/04/10/goldie-to-star-in-wings-of-desire/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-05-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120518093652/http://www.idfb.co.uk/news/2012/04/10/goldie-to-star-in-wings-of-desire/ |archivedate=18 May 2012 |df= }} "Wings of Desire"</ref> Other commercial endeavours included work for the likes of [[Warner Bros.]], [[MTV]], [[Nickelodeon]] and [[Channel 4]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pausefest.com.au/mrk-uk/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-05-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120630025019/http://www.pausefest.com.au/mrk-uk/ |archivedate=30 June 2012 |df= }} "PauseFest: MRK-UK"</ref> He also collaborated in the direction of the main titles for Dutch digital arts festival Playgrounds, which premiered in Amsterdam in November 2012.<ref>[http://watchthetitles.com/articles/00258-Playgrounds_Digital_Arts_Fest_2012]"Playgrounds Digital Arts Fest 2012"</ref> Later on that year he took part in another international collaboration "The Powers Project," a visual re-imagining of the [[Ray Eames|Eames]] classic [[Powers of Ten (film)|Powers of Ten]].<ref>[http://cargocollective.com/powersproject/MRK Powers Project]</ref> His segment was the first to be released as part of the promotion of the film.<ref>[http://thecreatorsproject.vice.com/blog/visually-recreating-ipowers-of-tensi-exploration-of-universes-tiny-and-massive Visually Recreating Powers Of Ten's Exploration Of Universes Tiny And Massive]</ref>
MRK's work fuses science with visual art.<ref>[http://www.stashmedia.tv/?p=9639] "Stash Magazine: MRK</ref> He deals with themes of [[emergence]], [[evolution]] and [[complexity]], as well as [[artificial life]] and [[generative art]] processes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jotta.com/jotta/published/home/article/v2-published/1942/spotlight-markos-kay-and-the-generative-flow |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-05-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140826160925/http://www.jotta.com/jotta/published/home/article/v2-published/1942/spotlight-markos-kay-and-the-generative-flow |archivedate=26 August 2014 |df= }} "Jotta: Markos Kay</ref> He is inspired by [[biological]] forms and processes, life and natural cycles, and [[deconstruction]] is a major influence.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.idfb.co.uk/news/2012/04/10/goldie-to-star-in-wings-of-desire/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-05-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120518093652/http://www.idfb.co.uk/news/2012/04/10/goldie-to-star-in-wings-of-desire/ |archivedate=18 May 2012 |df= }} "Wings of Desire</ref> Other areas of interest include: [[molecular biology]], [[digital physics]], [[information theory]] and [[complexity science]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.groopti.com/blog/index.php/inspiration/mrks-the-flow/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-05-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111025052954/http://www.groopti.com/blog/index.php/inspiration/mrks-the-flow/ |archivedate=25 October 2011 |df= }} "Groopti: MRK's The Flow"</ref>
==Filmography==
'''Notable Works''' * Playgrounds Main Titles (2012) * Powers Project (2012) * Vimeo Awards (2012) * Titanic 100th Anniversary (2012) * Insect Traps (2012) * The Flow (2011) * aDiatomea (2008) * Soundway: Introductory Video (2007) * SuprEgo (2006) * Yogoid (2005)
==Exhibits, screenings, publications== *Playgrounds Festival 2012 Amsterdam-Tilburg *Imagine Science Films 2012 New York *Refraction Kopparberg Unestablishment 2012 London *Van D'Or Awards 2012 London *Stash Magazine Issue 93 *Jotta Publication: Issue 1 *Screen Social 2012 London *OFFF 2012 Book *Resonance 2011 (International) *Onedotzero 2011 London *OFF 2011 Barcelona *Cut out Festival 2011 [ *Pause Fest 2011 Melbourne *Sonar 2011 Barcelona *Viedram 2011 Rome *Stroke Artfair 2001 Munich/Berlin *Wallace Space 2010 London *Phyletic Museum 2009–present Berlin *MACD 2008 London *We Are Here 2008 London
== References == {{reflist|2}}
==External links== * [http://www.mrkism.com MRK official website] * [http://vimeo.com/mrkism MRK Vimeo page] * [http://www.linkedin.com/in/mrkfolio MRK flickr page] * [http://www.behance.net/mrk MRK on Behance] * [http://www.mrkism.com/diatomea/ aDiatomea: Digitally Engineered Living Systems] * [http://www.mrkism.com/flow/ The Flow] * [http://watchthetitles.com/articles/00258-Playgrounds_Digital_Arts_Fest_2012 Playgrounds 2012 Titles] * [http://thecreatorsproject.com/blog/visually-recreating-ipowers-of-tensi-exploration-of-universes-tiny-and-massive Visually Recreating Powers Of Ten's Exploration Of Universes Tiny And Massive] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20140826160925/http://www.jotta.com/jotta/published/home/article/v2-published/1942/spotlight-markos-kay-and-the-generative-flow Jotta: Markos Kay and the Generative Flow] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20111025052954/http://www.groopti.com/blog/index.php/inspiration/mrks-the-flow/ Groopti: MRK’s The Flow] * [http://dataisnature.com/?p=564 Dataisnature: aDiatomea – Sonically Superformed Micro-organisms] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120630025019/http://www.pausefest.com.au/mrk-uk/ PauseFest: MRK UK]

{{DEFAULTSORT:MRK}} [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:British experimental filmmakers]] [[Category:British animators]] [[Category:Alumni of Central Saint Martins]] [[Category:Visual music artists]] [[Category:British video artists]] [[Category:British graphic designers]] [[Category:British illustrators]] [[Category:Scientific illustrators]]

'''Off-flavours''' or '''off-flavors''' (see [[American and British English spelling differences|spelling differences]]) are taints in food products caused by the presence of undesirable compounds. They can originate in raw materials, from chemical changes during food processing and storage, and from micro-organisms. Off-flavours are a recurring issue in [[drinking water]] supply and many [[food]] products.
Water bodies are often affected by [[geosmin]] and [[2-methylisoborneol]], affecting the flavour of water for drinking and of fish growing in that water.<ref>Robin, J. et al. (2006). Off flavour characterization and origin in French trout farming. Aquaculture, 260(1–4)</ref> Haloanisoles similarly affect water bodies, and are a recognised cause of off-flavour in [[wine]].<ref>Collins, T. S. et al. (2012). Analysis of Haloanisoles in Corks and Wines. In S. Toth & C. Mussinan (Eds.), Recent Advances in the Analysis of Food and Flavors (pp. 109–127). American Chemical Society.</ref> Cows grazing on [[weed]]s such as [[Ramsons|wild garlic]] can produce a ‘weedy’ off-flavour in [[milk]].<ref>Ridgway, K. (n.d.). Avoiding Customer Complaints: Origins of Food Taints and Off-flavours. RSSL.</ref>
Many more examples can be seen throughout food production sectors including in [[Oat#Kilning|oats]], [[Coffee cupping#Taste|coffee]], [[Glucose syrup#Preparation|glucose syrup]] and [[Brewing#Boiling|brewing]].
== References == {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=April 2013}} {{Infobox book | name = On Intelligence | title_orig = | translator = | image = OnInt.png | caption = Front Cover | author = [[Jeff Hawkins]] & [[Sandra Blakeslee]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | subject = [[Psychology]] | genre = | publisher = [[Times Books]] | release_date = 2004 | english_release_date = | media_type = [[Paperback]] | pages = 272 | isbn = 0-8050-7456-2 | dewey= 612.8/2 22 | congress= QP376 .H294 2004 | oclc= 55510125 | preceded_by = | followed_by = }}
'''''On Intelligence: How a New Understanding of the Brain will Lead to the Creation of Truly Intelligent Machines''''' is a 2004 book<ref>{{cite book|last1=Hawkins|first1=Jeff|title=On Intelligence|date=2004|publisher=Times Books|isbn=0805074562|pages=272|edition=1st}}</ref> by [[Palm (PDA)|Palm Pilot]]-inventor [[Jeff Hawkins]] with ''[[New York Times]]'' science writer [[Sandra Blakeslee]]. The book explains Hawkins' [[memory-prediction framework]] theory of the [[brain]] and describes some of its consequences.
==Outline== Hawkins outlines the book as follows:
{{Quote|The book starts with some background on why previous attempts at understanding intelligence and building intelligent machines have failed. I then introduce and develop the core idea of the theory, what I call the memory-prediction framework. In chapter 6 I detail how the physical brain implements the memory-prediction model—in other words, how the brain actually works. I then discuss social and other implications of the theory, which for many readers might be the most thought-provoking section. The book ends with a discussion of intelligent machines—how we can build them and what the future will be like. (p. 5)}}
==A personal history== The first chapter is a brief history of Hawkins' interest in neuroscience juxtaposed against a history of artificial intelligence research. Hawkins uses a story of his failed application to the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] to illustrate a conflict of ideas. Hawkins believed (and ostensibly continues to believe) creating true artificial intelligence will only be possible with intellectual progress in the discipline of neuroscience. Hawkins writes that the scientific establishment (as symbolized by MIT) has historically rejected the relevance of neuroscience to artificial intelligence. Indeed, some artificial intelligence researchers have "[taken] pride in ignoring neurobiology" (p. 12).
Hawkins is an [[electrical engineer]] by training, and a neuroscientist by inclination. He used electrical engineering concepts as well as the studies of neuroscience to formulate his framework. In particular, Hawkins treats the propagation of nerve impulses in our [[nervous system]] as an [[code|encoding problem]], specifically, a future predicting [[state machine]], similar in principle to [[feed forward (control)|feed-forward]] [[error-correcting]] state machines.
==The theory== {{main|Memory-prediction framework}} Hawkins' basic idea is that the brain is a mechanism to predict the future, specifically, hierarchical regions of the brain predict their future input sequences. Perhaps not always far in the future, but far enough to be of real use to an organism. As such, the brain is a [[Feed forward (control)|feed forward]] [[hierarchical state machine]] with special properties that enable it to [[learning|learn]].
The [[state machine]] actually controls the behavior of the organism. Since it is a [[Feed forward (control)|feed forward]] state machine, the machine responds to future events predicted from past data.
The hierarchy is capable of memorizing frequently observed sequences ([[Cognitive modules]]) of patterns and developing invariant representations. Higher levels of the cortical hierarchy predict the future on a longer time scale, or over a wider range of sensory input. Lower levels interpret or control limited domains of experience, or sensory or effector systems. Connections from the higher level states predispose some selected transitions in the lower-level state machines.
[[Hebbian learning]] is part of the framework, in which the event of learning physically alters neurons and connections, as learning takes place.
[[Vernon Mountcastle]]'s formulation of a [[cortical column]] is a basic element in the framework. Hawkins places particular emphasis on the role of the interconnections from peer columns, and the activation of columns as a whole. He strongly implies that a column is the cortex's physical representation of a state in a state machine.
As an engineer, any specific failure to find a natural occurrence of some process in his framework does not signal a fault in the memory-prediction framework ''per se'', but merely signals that the natural process has performed Hawkins' functional decomposition in a different, unexpected way, as Hawkins' motivation is to create intelligent [[machine]]s. For example, for the purposes of his framework, the nerve impulses can be taken to form a temporal sequence (but phase encoding could be a possible implementation of such a sequence; these details are immaterial for the framework).
==Predictions of the theory of the memory-prediction framework== His [[prediction]]s use the [[visual system]] as a prototype for some example predictions, such as Predictions 2, 8, 10, and 11. Other predictions cite the [[auditory system]] ( Predictions 1, 3, 4, and 7). *An Appendix of 11 Testable Predictions:
=== Enhanced neural activity in anticipation of a sensory event=== 1. In all areas of [[Cerebral cortex|cortex]], Hawkins (2004) predicts "we should find ''anticipatory cells''", cells that fire in anticipation of a sensory [[Phenomenon|event]]. :Note: As of 2005 [[mirror neuron]]s have been observed to fire ''before'' an anticipated event.<ref> {{cite journal | last1 = Fogassi | first1 = Leonardo | first2 = Pier Francesco | last2 = Ferrari | first3 = Benno | last3 = Gesierich | first4 = Stefano | last4 = Rozzi | first5 = Fabian | last5 = Chersi | first6 = Giacomo | last6 = Rizzolatti | date = April 29, 2005 | title = Parietal lobe: from action organization to intention understanding | journal = Science | volume = 308 | issue = 5722 | pages = 662–667 | doi = 10.1126/science.1106138 | pmid = 15860620 | url = http://www.unipr.it/arpa/mirror/pubs/pdffiles/Fogassi-Ferrari2005.pdf | accessdate = 2006-11-18 }}</ref>
=== Spatially specific prediction=== 2. In primary sensory [[Cerebral cortex|cortex]], Hawkins predicts, for example, "we should find anticipatory cells in or near [[Visual cortex#Primary visual cortex (V1)|V1]], at a precise location in the visual field (the scene)". It has been experimentally determined, for example, after mapping the angular position of some objects in the visual field, there will be a one-to-one correspondence of cells in the scene to the angular positions of those objects. Hawkins predicts that when the features of a visual scene are known in a memory, anticipatory cells should fire ''before'' the actual objects are seen in the scene.
=== Prediction should stop propagating in the cortical column at layers 2 and 3=== 3. In layers 2 and 3, predictive activity (neural firing) should stop propagating at specific cells, corresponding to a specific prediction. Hawkins does not rule out anticipatory cells in layers 4 and 5.
=== "Name cells" at layers 2 and 3 should preferentially connect to layer 6 cells of cortex=== 4. Learned sequences of firings comprise a representation of ''temporally constant invariants''. Hawkins calls the cells which fire in this sequence "name cells". Hawkins suggests that these ''name cells'' are in layer 2, physically adjacent to layer 1. Hawkins does not rule out the existence of layer 3 cells with dendrites in layer 1, which might perform as ''name cells''.
=== "Name cells" should remain ON during a learned sequence=== 5. By definition, a ''temporally constant invariant'' will be active during a learned sequence. Hawkins posits that these cells will remain active for the duration of the learned sequence, even if the remainder of the cortical column is shifting state. Since we do not know the encoding of the sequence, we do not yet know the definition of ''ON'' or ''active''; Hawkins suggests that the ON pattern may be as simple as a simultaneous [[logical and|AND]] (i.e., the name cells simultaneously "light up") across an array of name cells. :See [[Neural ensemble#Encoding]] for ''grandmother neurons'' which perform this type of function.
=== "Exception cells" should remain OFF during a learned sequence === 6. Hawkins' novel prediction is that certain cells are inhibited during a learned sequence. A class of cells in layers 2 and 3 should NOT fire during a learned sequence, the axons of these "exception cells" should fire ''only if a local prediction is failing''. This prevents flooding the brain with the usual sensations, leaving only exceptions for post-processing.
=== "Exception cells" should propagate unanticipated events=== 7. If an unusual event occurs (the learned sequence fails), the "exception cells" should fire, propagating up the cortical hierarchy to the [[hippocampus]], the repository of new memories.
=== "Aha! cells" should trigger predictive activity === 8. Hawkins predicts a cascade of predictions, when recognition occurs, propagating down the cortical column (with each [[saccade]] of the [[human eye|eye]] over a learned scene, for example).
=== Pyramidal cells should detect coincidences of synaptic activity on thin dendrites=== 9. [[Pyramidal cell]]s should be capable of detecting coincident events on thin [[dendrite]]s, even for a [[neuron]] with thousands of [[synapse]]s. Hawkins posits a temporal window (presuming time-encoded firing) which is necessary for his [[theory]] to remain viable.
=== Learned representations move down the cortical hierarchy, with training === 10. Hawkins posits, for example, that if the inferotemporal (IT) layer has learned a sequence, that eventually cells in V4 will also learn the sequence.
==="Name cells" exist in all regions of cortex=== 11. Hawkins predicts that "name cells" will be found in all regions of the cortex.
== See also == * [[Hierarchical temporal memory]], a technology by Hawkins's startup [[Numenta]] Inc. to replicate the properties of the neocortex. * [[Memory-prediction framework]]
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == * {{official website|http://www.onintelligence.com}} * {{cite journal | citeseerx = 10.1.1.132.6744 | title = A Hierarchical Bayesian Model of Invariant Pattern Recognition in the Visual Cortex | first1 = Dileep | last1 = George | first2 = Jeff | last2 = Hawkins }} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20061013134333/http://www.phillylac.org/prediction/ Saulius Garalevicius' research page] - Research papers and programs presenting experimental results with Bayesian models of the Memory-Prediction Framework * [http://sourceforge.net/projects/neocortex/ Project Neocortex] - An open source project for modeling Memory-Prediction Framework
=== Reviews === * {{cite journal | url = http://www.computer.org/computer/homepage/0105/random/index.htm | title = Machine Intelligence Meets Neuroscience | first = Bob | last = Colwell | publisher = [[IEEE]] | journal = Computer | volume = 38 | issue = 1 | pages = 12–15 | date = January 2005 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20050204164903/http://www.computer.org/computer/homepage/0105/random/index.htm | archivedate = 2005-02-04 | doi = 10.1109/MC.2005.24 }} ** {{cite web | url = http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/iel5/2/30112/01381247.pdf | title = Machine Intelligence Meets Neuroscience | format = full text for IEEE Explore's online subscribers | subscription=yes}} * [http://future.iftf.org/2004/10/jeff_hawkins_on.html A review by Franz Dill] * [http://www.techcentralstation.com/article.aspx?id=112204B On Intelligence, People and Computers] (Arnold Kling, Tech Central Station, 22 November 2004) * [http://www.goertzel.org/dynapsyc/2004/OnBiologicalAndDigitalIntelligence.htm On Biological and Digital Intelligence] A review by [[Ben Goertzel]] (7 Oct 2004)
[[Category:2004 books]] [[Category:Science books]] [[Category:Artificial intelligence publications]] [[Category:Books about human intelligence]]

{{Unreferenced|date=November 2008}} [[File:Orbites definition.png|thumb|250px|right|Six schemes of circumstellar orbit]]
'''Outer-grazer''' and '''inner-grazer''' are configurations of [[heliocentric orbit]]. All six diagrams show the [[Sun]] (the orange dot) in the middle and a putative [[planet]]'s [[orbit]]al band (in yellow). The latter is a ring whose inner radius is the planet's [[perihelion]] and its outer radius the [[aphelion]].
* ''Middle, top'': The minor planet's orbit enters the other planet's orbit from the inside without traversing it; it is an inner-grazer. * ''Middle, bottom'': The minor planet's orbit enters the planet's from outside without traversing it; it is an outer-grazer.
==See also== *[[Earth-grazing fireball]], a meteor that grazes Earth's atmosphere rather than the planet's orbit
[[Category:Space science]] [[Category:Orbits]]
